Explanation:
The original statement is a conditional statement: "If Sue chose pizza, then Bob chose pasta." This can be represented as P -> Q, where P is "Sue chose pizza" and Q is "Bob chose pasta."

We want to determine if we can infer "If Bob did not choose pasta, then Sue did not choose pizza." This can be represented as ~Q -> ~P, where ~Q means "Bob did not choose pasta" and ~P means "Sue did not choose pizza."

The statement ~Q -> ~P is the contrapositive of the original statement P -> Q. A fundamental principle of logic states that a conditional statement is logically equivalent to its contrapositive. In other words, if P -> Q is true, then ~Q -> ~P is also true, and vice versa.

Therefore, since we are given "If Sue chose pizza, then Bob chose pasta" (P -> Q), we *can* infer "If Bob did not choose pasta, then Sue did not choose pizza" (~Q -> ~P).



Answer: yes
